Normal.summary: A defining feature of the normal distribution is that the mean, mode and median are equal, resulting in its iconic ‘Bell-shaped’, symmetrical probability distribution curve. >Most physical characteristics naturally exhibit a normal distribution, and many other distributions at scale tend towards it (courtesy of the Central Limit Theorem).

Poisson.summary: The Poisson distribution comes in handy when modeling the number of times an event occurs in a given time interval. >Say for example a shop gets on average 10 customers every hour, then the Poisson distribution could help study and predict customer visiting patterns.

Bernoulli.summary: The Bernoulli distribution models situations which could go only one of two possible ways (success or failure, with probabilities p and q = 1-p respectively) e.g. a coin toss. >If the two events are equally likely, p = 0.5.

Uniform.summary: In uniform distributions, all values have equal probability. A good example is rolling a (fair) die; all six faces have the same odds of topping (probability = 1/6). >All the values in a uniformly distributed interval (a,b) have probability 1/(b-a).

Geometric.summary: The Geometric distribution models the number of tries it will take before registering the first success. >Examples include estimating the number of failures before an experiment succeeds, or an athlete hits a target.

Alpha.summary: The Alpha distribution is widely applied in models and tests for reliability and lifetime.

Beta.summary: The Beta distribution has many applications in Bayesian inference, which attempts to determine the likelihood of events based on some prior condition or knowledge.

Chi Squared.summary: The chi-square distribution is derived from the summation of standardized & squared normally distributed variables. >It is essential in tests for hypotheses, since most test statistics are approximately chi-square distributed.

Exponential.summary: The Exponential distribution models the time intervals between events occurring at a constant rate (having a Poisson distribution). >It can help analyse the inter-arrival times of customers: how long a stall will stay idle before the next customer comes along, assuming 40 customers come in every hour.

F.summary: The F distribution is crucial in tests of hypothesis using the Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) methods.
F.param_info: ν >0(degrees of freedom), ω > 0 (degrees of freedom)

Gamma.summary: The Gamma family of distributions has many research applications, most notably in predicting rainfall and designing models that exhibit certain characteristics to allow prototyping.

Pareto.summary: The Pareto distribution models features where a large proportion of observations come from a small amount of variables: most notably the imbalances in income distribution, human settlement patterns and error rates.

Students t.summary: The Student’s t-test is very useful for estimating the mean of small, normally distributed samples; and for testing the significance of the difference in two sample means.

Binomial.summary: The Binomial distribution models the number of success for n Bernoulli trials (succeed or fail scenarios). >A common application is determining whether a desired threshold will be met given a predetermined fail rate.
Binomial.param_info: n > 0 (no. of trials), 0<=p<=1 (defaults to 0.5 for p>1)

Negative Binomial.summary: The Negative Binomial distribution models the number of successes before the ith failure. >A possible application is in predicting the number of wins before the third failure, given the likelihood of success on each attempt.
Negative Binomial.param_info: n > 0 (no. of trials), 0<=p<=1 (defaults to 0.5 for p>1)
